title: Counts slowly out loud--perfect for exercises
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 25, 2019
content: Update: Thank you developers for returning the slow  counting speed back to its previous slow speed. This app is the ONLY one available that simply counts out loud. Not a stopclock, not a metronome, not a child' learn numbers tool. I'm back to happily giving this app a 5-star review.Previous: I've been happily using this app for over a year to count reps for some exercises I do and up until today, I would have given it a 5 star review. I liked that I could ask the count to be VERY SLOW. Today, that slow speed has dramatically increased, preventing me from being able to complete a weight lift in time before the next number is counted. Developer, please revert to the timing speed you used prior to today.

title: please confirm with a parental "UNIT"
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: it's basic . .. and asks:"is your room tidy?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"have you practiced your instrument?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"is your homework done?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"are your chores done?"  if you answer Yes, it next asks:"do you have screen time (TV) privileges?"  if you answer Yes, it says"congratulation you have screentime, please confirm with a parental unit."if you answer No, it says "No Screens for you" ...I about fell on the floor laughing when it said please confirm with a parental "UNIT".I hate to brag but I, yes me, She Who is Unnamed, I, invented the phrase parental unit, I started saying that well OVER 35 plus years ago. That's why I am laughing. And why I added an extra üåü. But a 3 star rating is because, as follows:if adjusting the questions were available this would be better, considering every student doesn't play an instrument, and since a majority of schools have eliminated their music programs, and every child who might want to play an instrument doesn't always have access to instruments to practice, but they might have something else that the ability to change or adjust "practice" here would apply, or be able to insert options for special projects in addition to homework...  also, customizing options, to be able to adjust by person... Not all children are the same, even in the same family.  But this is an awesome starting for an app of this type. wish this was availaible when my kids were little - 25 plus years too late - one last side note would be to add features for grandma's, for when the little ones visit.

title: There's just no substitute for real parenting
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 24, 2016
content: Dev clearly does not have children. What's stopping the kid from saying yes to all questions just to get screen time? Better yet, what's stopping the kid from just turning on the TV? Alexa? I don't think so. Who's going to do quality control? "Did you do your HW?" "Yes" "Did you answer all questions? Let me see/check." Oh wait, you can't. Technology can make your life easier but in this case it just can't replace a real parent.

title: Worked Great Until I Bought a New Phone
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 4, 2021
content: Alexa allows you to remove your old device via voice but when you want to add a new device, she gives you the PIN code to input. Sounds easy enough but there is nowhere to input that code to add your new device. Try the skill "Find My Phone" instead...it's easy to set up and, once you do, all you have to do is tell Alexa "find my phone" you don't have to go through answering "what should I do? Find, add, or remove device".  It even shows up on your caller ID as "find my phone".  A lot more user friendly than this skill.

title: Saves me a lot of time

content: My phone is always on my desk or night stand... usually. But when it isn't it could be anywhere. Phone finder lets me know if the phone is in my apartment. Because it could be in the car. Or back at work. Or, well, you get the idea. Great app.

title: Remember to say the right thing!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 19, 2019
content: Works great but you have to remember to say "Alexa, "use phone finder to find my phone", and not say "alexa "find my phone". Apparently not everyone realized that, at at least one reviewer complained it trys to call your phone and if it's on silent it won't ring. It does that only if yoy say "alexa find my phone", thats a different skill! if you have this one enabled and say "Alexa use phone finder to find my phone" it sets off a loud alarm on the phone even if it's on silent, it works!

title: New and improved...premium

Would really like that shortened or customizable to "find my phone".  Maybe someday they will improve the Routines to do this.

title: Works perfectly, just test it
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 4, 2018
content: This app work perfectly. To people whining about lack of iOS support, this is due to limitations in Apple's phone OS that make it difficult to create apps that modify/override system settings (like phone volume) among whatever other good reasons the dev has.For Android just make sure that it works under various conditions. Ensure that it can override do not disturb and that the app isn't being killed to save battery life, etc. Works perfectly.

title: Hmmmm...BACON
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 4, 2017
content: I was skeptical but this skill has the word "pizza" in it -- not to mention a friendly looking slice of pizza as the icon -- so I had to try it. Turns out, it was actually pretty good (just like the pizza I ate). I was afraid it would be a cheesy app that tells me facts about pizza, but instead, it was different. This skill tries to compare two pizzas to see which is the better deal. I like that it was interactive and you don't have to enter everything in one mouthful. After entering the company name, it then prompts you for the size, and finally the price, and so on.  It then tells you which pizza is cheaper per square inch. So you could compare a large and a medium by the same pizza seller, and see if you should get the large for a little more, or the medium for a little less. In my case, the large did save me a few cents per square inch.  It would be 5 stars if it could tell me how much I will save by ordering the pizza it recommends. For example it could say "the large is 2 cents per square inch cheaper. Your large pizza is xxx square inches, so you will save $1.96 by buying the large". Overall, a highly recommended app for all the pizza eaters out there. It might save you some dough. Would be interested to hear what others think. (By the way, anchovies is small fish pickled in oil, in case you are new to pizza. Does anyone actually like fish on their pizza?)

title: Great idea - but lots of improvements needed to make ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2018
content: Great idea - but lots of improvements needed to make it a super-skill! For example, it would be great to sit down to a practice session and tell alexa to start a timer - and when you complete your practice - tell Alexa your practice session has ended. Also it would be nice to ask Alexa to email you a graphical summary of your practice times,,, etc -- lots of possibilities to make it a First-Class skill... If you need help, make it an open-source skill and we'll all jump in and help!

title: Is this the I am soooo drunk and need to go to the bar app or what?
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 20, 2016
content: What I really wanted was multiple to do lists in the Alexa app so I can break tasks down into categories but so far that isn't possible. So I searched skills for additional to do lists that might have that ability but didn't find anything... However, I did see this skill and I thought maybe I could at least get one more reminder list. Nope. First off, it was hard for me to launch...Alexa just kept adding 'keys' to my to do list, which I then have to go to the app and clear.. finally did get it launched and here is what it asked me.... Do I have my keys? Do I have my ID?  Do I have a payment method? Ummmm.... really? if you can't remember that stuff then you are probably drunk. So if you frequently head down to the bar when you are already drunk and can't remember what to take then this is probably a great app for you. If the questions were modifiable it wouldn't be bad but with only the canned questions it is pretty useless.

title: Meh, is okay. Very basic.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 13, 2016
content: This would be a five star app if only you were able to customize it. Instead of saying "Alexa open remember your keys" you should be able to say "Alexa, I'm leaving" or "Alexa, am I forgetting something?" And then Alexa can remind you of the items you want to be reminded of when leaving the house.

title: I keep frequently forget my phone when I leave the ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 18, 2017
content: I  frequently forget my phone when I leave the house. I don't understand how  is this app going to help me if I forget to ask Alexa to  to tell me if I have everything I need. A more  helpful app  for a forgetful person such as myself would allow me to preprogram  Alexa to ask me,  in a soft voice, at  a set time in the morning, " Before you leave, check that you you have everything  you need". Or I could stick a poster  on my exit door  that reads, in big, bold, red letters "Check for  your phone you doofus".

title: Needs personalization - an index card is better
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 19, 2018
content: As other reviewers stated, this isn't very helpful without the ability to personalize it. For example, it asks if I have my electronic devices. It's up to me to remember that I need to bring my phone, Kindle, Pok√©mon button, Fitbit, tablet, etc.  depending on where I am going.  At that point I am doing all the work. It doesn't ask me if I have my MetroCard, which is the thing I forget most often. I keep a list of things I need on the door, and for now that's way more useful.I am also going to try to design one via Blueprint. It would be nice to be reminded to bring my handkerchief, lip balm, pills, a sweater, etc while I am still packing.The designers of this need to realize that their list falls way short for most people, as our lives vary widely. There are millions of people who live in cities and need bus or train passes to go out!

title: Too many questions
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 17, 2017
content: I agree with the other reviewers. There should be a way to categorize a list. I would love to just say Alexa leaving for work and have her run down a check list of what I need before I leave.

Perhaps grouping items with single names, such as "keys, phone, and water" for each question.

title: Terrible App
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2021
content: If you can get it to actually play, the ‚Äúshh‚Äù sound is good. But every time I ask Alexa to play/open Baby Shush, she starts playing the song Baby Shark...which is maybe the worst song ever when you‚Äôre trying to get your baby to sleep. Obviously people are using this app to get their kid to fall asleep, so it‚Äôs really annoying that every time you launch the app, Alexa tells you the directions of how to listen and how to pause (why does she feels the need to explain this?). And worse yet, once you‚Äôve got your kid fast asleep and you ask Alexa to stop the app, she says ‚ÄúTHANKS FOR LISTENING!‚Äù, and wakes up the baby!! Why in the world an app designed to put and keep babies asleep is so poorly designed, I do not understand.Not recommended. Just download a free shush or white noise app on your phone.

title: Ignore the dimwits:  This is a GeoIP lookup, not a Whois lookup.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 28, 2020
content: Whois lookups against IP addresses, when they work at all, return the IP owner's address, not where the IP is in use.GeoIP lookups, which this skill employs, utilize databases to report the physical location of the IP address.So rather than tell you that every dynamic IP address given out by Cox Communications is in Atlanta, GA (the location of Cox's corporate headquarters), this skill uses a database to try to determine where the IP is actually in use.Four stars just because all GeoIP databases are incomplete and have outdated and erroneous entries.  It's not a comment on the developer, who is using the same databases that all of us network pros use for this.

If Im whispering, WHY ARE YOU YELLING UR WORDS and keep playing TRAFFIC HORNS and ugly noises in literally ALL ‚Äúnaptime‚Äù ‚Äúwhite sounds‚Äù ‚Äúbaby‚Äù....‚Äùskills‚Äù?? Amazon needs to work on itself and remember these go in our HOMES. Alexa: reflect on this and then please start reflecting our variety.

title: Does not recognize my event.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 11, 2017
content: Does not work correctly for "Maui" or "Hawaii".  Tried both, but when saying "Alexa, Ask Days Until, How Long Until Hawaii?" it replies with "Sure, what event?" every time.  I am asking it the exact phrase it told me to ask it when setting up the event, so I'm not sure why it doesn't work.  And when I say "Hawaii" after it asks me for what event, it hears me fine, so I know it's recognizing the word "Hawaii".  Same exact problem with "Maui".  Also, I should be able to just say "Alexa, Ask Days Until Hawaii", rather than "Ask Days Until, How Long Until Hawaii" -- that is a mouthful, and hard to remember.  Or better yet: "Alexa, Days Until Hawaii".  It would be a great skill if it worked like that -- I would use it every day.

title: Not correct time zone
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
content: Days Until seem to change at GMT and not the time zone on the device. Example, in Chicago at 6:55 there are 5 days until event. At 7:05 there is now only 4 days. Days do not change at midnight.Difficulty adding events due to the Alexa device listening to early...... using her own voice as part of the answer. Every event would be called 'Event' unless I spoke prevoius to her finishing the question. Some small delays in question/answer are needed.Events work great, entry can be challeging. Time zone should be fixed, surprized I do not see this stated on other reviews.

title: Akward, redundant
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 17, 2020
content: Why use this app when you can just say "Alexa how many days until (insert date)".  This app would be good if there was an option to have it announce every day at a specific time, "How many days until __________" without having to ask rvery time.

title: great when you follow instructions
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 12, 2019
content: Be sure to review the available phrases!  i.e. "Alexa, ask Days Until to create a new countdown.". Then, Alexa will ask for the information (name & date) to properly create the upcoming event.  She'll also confirm the details.  Try it out right away (Alexa, ask Days Until how long until {your named event}?) It works well, if you follow the instructions!

Amazon, delete this from the store and give the phrase to someone else who can make a skill like this that works.

The biggest issue is the reason I enabled this skill is to use my "good morning" routine. While you can add the skill to any routine, the skill insists on being the last skill on the list. title: Worked Great for 1 year
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 31, 2021
content: Used to love this system.  Worked flawlessly for a year.  Then the founder passed and I can only assume they began cutting corners.  First, shore power sensor defect led to "disconnect immediately, risk of fire"....took months to receive replacement.  Next, an update to their app broke notifications.  They argued that I never should have received those notications in the first place before admitting they had changed the behavior of the app.  Then came a fix, and the ability to switch from armed to aboard to disarmed stopped working.  They argued it "must be your provider", even though my cell and the system had full connection  and I would receive notifications about shore power immediately.  Then they admitted the app was broken.  Several subsequent "fixes" fixed nothing.  After 7 months the system still does not work, and their solution is that I should buy a manual switch and install it in a discrete location.  Their support is horrible, they lie and argue about their bad software, and expect the customer to spend money to fix their mistakes, all while continuing to charge a subscription fee.  Do yourself a favor a look at other products.

title: Decent, but with annoying bug.
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 8, 2020
content: The good: It's simple and effective.  It ticks off seconds and notifies you in ten second intervals how many have passed.  For things like stretching and short exercises, it's what I want.  It tells you the total time when you stop it.The bad: When you stop it, it doesn't close.  That could mean when you run something else and tell that thing to stop, Time Tone responds as if you just told it to stop (repeats time elapsed).  Sometimes that prevents the other thing from stopping.  Other times when you try to get Echo to do something, you will be told you can't do it because Time Tone is open.  You have to unplug the Echo to get Time Tone to stop.

title: could be super useful but needs tons of work
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 27, 2016
content: concept was exciting. actual use disappointing. lacks full household or any other functionality besides just checking for feeding the dog.  basic use words like laundry or garbage or took my vitamins, it has no recognition for and was attempted by two different people trying to speak with it. if you say anything to it all it recognizes is that you fed the dog.  will be a great and useful app someday.  just need Tons of work. also would be great improvement if a time value could be added to be recorded with the log entry so i could tell it that i cooked and stored the chicken leftover dish on friday at 7pm so that when i go find it in the fridge and need to know how long its been there it can tell me. we'll check back and look forward to there being some kind of progress on this potentially really great skill. for now its useless unless your dog eats a lot.

title: I can't get "Alexa" to understand the word "noteboard". ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 29, 2016
content: I can't get "Alexa" to understand the word "noteboard"... I bought the echo dot for my mother with mild dementia to help her make notes to remember where things are and we can't get this very important app to work.  I asked "Alexa, tell noteboard my keys are in the basket" and it doesn't understand what I'm saying... we did the voice training to make sure it could understand...This app has a lot of potential, but not there yet.  I think the word "noteboard" is hard for device to understand... it comes up "know board", "not bored", "no board"

title: OK for dog or cat feeding note only.

If yiu vary at all she will not understand. If you try to leave any other message she talks about dishes. Pretty funny but not helpful. Will use for dog feeding after teaching family the exact phrase. It could have been much more useful.

title: Useful with limited features; could be great with more work.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 3, 2016
content: It seems useful if all you want to do is record when you fed the "cat" or "dog" and that "the dishes are dirty" or "the dishes are clean".  It seems to expect to hear only those commands, and if you give it something else it may think you gave it one of those.  It'd be great if it could record more kinds of things or let users define their own.  For example, I have two dogs and would like to note their feedings by their names.  Or I'd like to note when I took my medicine or that I gave my dog hers.  Or brushed the dog's teeth.

title: Cool concept, bad implimentation. Bug explaination and instructions below.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 1, 2019
content: if you tell it that you put something "on" something else then it triggers Alexas "turn on" function. So Alexa will cancel out butler and search for devices that she can turn on for you. (or at least that's what it seems like is happening) Which is super frustrating and probably a quick fix for an experienced programmer; a check to see if your using butler and then don't kick the user back out to alexa. This has apparently been a problem since the second top rated review which was posted in 2017, 2 years ago. So I'm disappointed that it hasn't been fixed and I don't think it will be fixed soon. If you plan to use this app, it will be good for you to know that you have to tell it you put stuff "IN" stuff because otherwise it bugs out. and it also doesn't seem to know the word "near" or "under". Just "IN"Also there are a lot of glitches calling Mr. Butler up, almost everytime Alexa will not recognize that your trying to use the skill and ask if you want to use the skill. when you say yes. she just kinda goes "just ask" leaving me sitting here going "Just ask what?" and I still haven't figure it out. it would help if she spelled out the kind of questions you should ask for mr. Butler.over all since starting to write this review I have dropped my rating by a star and told Alexa to disable Mr. Butler. Maybe when I get more competent with programming I can make us all a better Butler.

date: Reviewed in the United States on August 28, 2017

title: Major Bug! Don‚Äôt Enable This!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 14, 2021
content: Yes, you can set an alarm via Routines. Yes, it stops when you say Alexa, Stop. However, as others stated, it responds that the skill is paused and to say Resume to restart it. That does not sound so bad, but it is. From then on, any time tou tell Alexa to stop doing anything, be it Spotify or another skill, it replies, Morning Rooster can help you with that‚Äî which gets really old really quickly. Even deleting the routine and disabling the skill did not fix it. There are other rooster alarms out there that will not do this. Do not get this one unless you want to reboot your device to get rid of the annoying, repetitive glitch that will hound you any time you use Alexa to turn off anything else.

title: Great idea, clumsy execution
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 6, 2019
content: I love the idea of this app, but I hate its awkwardness. To get it to work requires three commands and the patience to listen to a verbose explanation.  Sigh. First, you cannot say "Tell Audible Clock to  set..." because it doesn't get it.  So,  first you have to open the app. Then, when it's open,  you have to sit through a 20- second instruction of how to choose a specific clock, even if you already know all this.  Then, after you've chosen a specific clock, you have to have yet another conversation about how often you want the clock to chime/speak/ whatever. To add more frustration,  the clock needs to be reset if other skills are used. Technology is supposed to make my life simpler, not busier. I will not subscribe to the premium version unless these problems are solved.

title: Love this app
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2021
content: Great app! If you want it to run non-stop without Alexa terminating the app upon a request, there‚Äôs a work around, but it involves two Alexa Echo ‚Äúdevices‚Äù in the same room, as your going to set this app up to have its own dedicated Echo. This method has been working for me for many months. Set this app up as you normally would initally. Create a Routine for it so it will start the app at the time you choose, but be sure to select the second Echo in the Routine as the device that the app will play the audio from. You also need to make sure that the Echo that plays the audio is always muted so it doesn‚Äôt respond to requests & terminate the running app. Your essentially giving the app its own ‚Äúspeaker.‚Äù Note, if your Echo is muted, when it looses power or reboots, it will still be muted when it cones back on, so no need to push the mute button everytime it reboots. So, I placed my second Echo running this app by my TV where its out of sight, & its like I have the real thing in the room when it chimes. A couple of pointers or suggestions. The app wont restart in the event the Echo is rebooted or unplugged, you‚Äôll have to manually run the Routine or wait for the Routine to run again at the scheduled time. I did find if you make two Routines to run the app twice a day, thats a good solution for this. Tip, if using two Routines to restart the app daily, try adding a volume change to the two Routines. If you set one Routine in the morning at full volume & one at night at very low volume, every time the Routine runs it will adjust the volume for you while restarting the app, this is something I found very useful at night when sleeping. Again no need to worry about muting it, it will remain muted until you unmute it manually regardless of what the Routine does with the volume. If you set it up this way, you‚Äôll give it five stars.

title: Ship's bell clock for Alexa
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 21, 2019
content: As an "old salt" I already have a chiming ships clock  in th family room.  But I also wanted the sound in my office.  Started looking around and "Audible Clock" came to rescue and put one up  that it works with Alexa.  So now my office echo chimes the hour and half hour as old sailing ships did to let the crew know of the passage of time as they stood their watches during the day.  So if you want to try, download the APP and tell Alexa ... "Alexa, ask Audible Clock for a Ship's Bell."

title: I'm loving it (5‚ô¶), but had to jump through hoops to get it to work consistently (-2‚ô¶)
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 11, 2022
content: After several attempts I now have a working 'Westminster Grandfather' sounds!  Love that it ticks all the time and that you can hear the full fade of the hourly bongs long after they strike.  But here's what I had to do to get it to work consistently (following others' advice here in the reviews/comments):1) You must have a dedicated dot else every other interaction with your dot will stop the app.2) I setup a routine to start the clock and can use it to restart in the event of a power blip or random interruption. I couldn't just ask the Dot to start the app as it kept starting the "Audible" book app instead.3) Once you start the app, you have to manually tell it which clock to use.  I couldn't add that to the routine.4) Once the clock is started, MUTE the microphone on the dot.  This dot will ONLY be used for the clock and nothing else.5) Go into your Alexa app and to this dedicated device.  I called mine Clock Dot.  Turn OFF the COMMUNICATIONS for this dot.  If you don't every delivery notification, reminder, alarm, whatever, will stop the app and you'll have to restart again.6) My clock has now been running for several days without interruption.

title: Big Ben and Me

And now I have Big Ben back.  And I'm oh so happy.  I just ordered one of the new Echo Dot Clocks so I can move my current Echo Spot to a more central location and have it dedicated to only chiming Ben.

title: How to make it work.
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 7, 2019
content: It's hard to set up. And it stops when you do other things on Alexa. So here's what I did. Go to the Alexa app and click on "more" on the bottom right. Then click on routines. Now make a routine for every hour to start the clock. I set mine a minute before the hour so it has time to launch then chime. Set one for every hour you want to be certain the clock works. Alexa chimes without fail now. Sometimes we get a weird hourly chime at exactly 10 minutes after the hour. I haven't figured that out yet. But it does work!

title: Very very much still in beta
date: Reviewed in the United States on July 23, 2017
content: Good concept, however it's very underwhelming. I asked alexa for the safety rating for New York City just for kicks, I was greeted with "I'm not sure wich city you wanted the after rating for, try again" I asked trying all 3 ways this page suggests saying New York City, The City of New York, New York, Manhattan, Brooklyn, the neighborhood of Manhattan and nothing. I then tried Baltimore, Detroit, Chicago, Philadelphia, London, Vancouver, Buenos Aires even Los Angeles didn't work the first 2 times. San Francisco, LA and Irvine are the only cities I got to work. Also, not to mention Alexa just responds with "very safe" "safe" or "unsafe"... Ok, it's is like Lisbon were I'll be robbed or Detroit were ill be shot. Also a distant feature might be adding a way to check specific neighborhoods in a city. Example, Essex in Baltimore is very unsafe while Canton is a very safe area is a very nice area so calling the whole city safe or unsafe is gross over generalization. Add way more cities, a justification for its rating and neighborhoods then you got a real app. This is just a silly meme.

title: A Skill that is not fully developed - Half Baked Skill -
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 27, 2019
content: Did someone start this "skill" and then abandon it?  Only 2 ports are know - SMTP and 90 - Nice Idea - Implementation is not conducive to natural speaking. It requires Alexa to open the Skill rather than stored in immediate memory. If space is a limitation, then the skill needs to include Alexa's ability to direct the user, as needed. Alexa should not speak like a computer saying do you want to open something. It should be more like I have a database I can consult regarding the SMTP Port or Port blah blah.Maybe there isn't enough interest for this kind of tool. Course, who's got Alexa sitting on their workstation ready to take order?  In corporate environment?  Hmm, maybe that's why the project was abandoned.? the consumer would careless about knowing ports and services.1 Star - Effort Minimal and Implementation failed.

title: Works

content: 'Open Stopwatch, and Start' - the stopwatch is now running. Only then does Alexa tell me that there is a stopwatch already in progress. Ugh. Dear Developers, please include a reply in the programming of this skill so that one knows that the request has been heard and complied. Even in Star Trek, a simple response is the base of all operations. If Hollywood gets it you would like to think that the rest of the world would get it as well.

title: Absolute Worst app / skill I have ever had.
date: Reviewed in the United States on September 25, 2021
content: This "skill" is one of the most annoying tech experiences I have ever had (and I've had AOL dial-up, so that's saying something).  What an obnoxious waste of time.  I haven't used the skill in years, because I couldn't get it to work properly.  I finally thought I'd try it again to see if it had been updated.  After asking multiple times in multiple ways to turn on the skill or add a new stopwatch, alexa finally told me that my stopwatch was running at 900-some days.  She then announced all of the things the app can do and would not stop talking.  I was unable to say anything to convince alexa to stop, the timer or delete the program, so I had to check a bunch of skills on the amazon site, all titled Stopwatch, to find which one was enabled, so I could disable it.  have no idea why this "skill" is still available on amazon.  What a nightmare!

title: Best available stopwatch skill
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 4, 2018
content: This seems to be the best of the available stopwatch skills, which sadly isn't saying much. I really waffled about whether to give it 3 or 4 stars, and finally decided on 4 because I'll only have to remember 2 commands - launch and stop - and it will let me play music at the same time. That is what I need a stopwatch skill for.- There is a lot of variation in the command format. For example, "Alexa, launch stopwatch" or "Alexa, start stopwatch" starts a new stopwatch if one isn't already running - otherwise it gives you the status of the one running. But "Alexa, status stopwatch" or "Alexa, stopwatch status" doesn't work. "Alexa, stop stopwatch" also produces the status but does NOT stop the stopwatch. You have to say "Alexa, ask stopwatch to stop" to actually end it. Is it really necessary to use such a roundabout format?- For actually using it, pretty much count on having to say "Alexa, ask stopwatch to" (pause, resume, stop). The simpler "Alexa, launch stopwatch" will start it or give you the status.- As others have said, this isn't a precision function. I just want to time how long I can pedal on the exercise bike, so a few seconds' variation won't make a difference to me. But if seconds matter to you, there isn't an Alexa skill that will meet your needs.- More important to me, this runs in the background so I can have Alexa play music while I am on the exercise bike and still keep track of my time.

title: Not that great
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 13, 2018
content: I  had to come to the comments to figure out how to cancel the stopwatch. I feel like I would have liked it a lot better if I could just say, "Alexa, stop stopwatch".

title: Phrasing is not intuitive
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 27, 2020
content: I hate shaving. Today I decided to actually time how long it takes so I would have no excuse not to shave. "Dude, it takes three minutes, just do it!.." would be my self talk. Decided to use the stopwatch feature on Alexa. Started easily but I could not figure out how to stop it. "Stop stopwatch was my command. Then end stopwatch. Neither worked. She would either tell me to cancel notifications by going to setting or she did not know what I was asking. Had to go online to find out the correct, very odd, phrasing. Shaving took me two hours and 18 minutes today.

title: Ooof!
date: Reviewed in the United States on February 15, 2021
content: Ooof! Nothing about this was intuitive. It took 2 minutes to figure out the phraseology needed to get it to stop. I could say "Start stopwatch," but not "Stop stopwatch." (For those looking for answers, it's "ask stopwatch to stop/pause".) And because stop and shop should similar, it kept trying to give m prices for stopwatches. title: This is what works for me.
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 3, 2022
content: Other reviews complain about how to make this skill work.  Maybe you might complain about needing to say a word or two more then absolutely needed, but these phrases work for me:  "Alexa, ask stopwatch to start" (it will tell you if it is already running).  "Alexa, ask stopwatch to stop" (it will tell you the current stopwatch time before stopping).  "Alexa, ask stopwatch to pause" (it will tell you the current stopwatch time before pausing).  "Alexa, ask stopwatch to resume".  "Alexa, ask stopwatch status" (it will tell you the current stopwatch time).  "Alexa, ask stopwatch to restart" (it will tell you the stopwatch time, and then start over from zero).  I always start with "Alexa, ask stopwatch ...", but there may be commands that don't need the word "ask".  I just say it to be consistent.

title: Here's how the app responds to questions:
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 6, 2019
content: I've had Alexa for about a week now, and am seriously considering returning all of the dot units. The usefulness of Alexa is bleak at best, and a waste of my time on most instances when I'm interacting with Alexa. The following is a typical interaction I have with Alexa on any given day attempting to learn something valuable. I am posting the results of some of my questions to show what a waste of my time Alexa really is...Question:"Alexa, ask planetary ephemeris where all planets are located in Portland.Alexa:"Sorry, I had trouble doing what you asked, please try again."Question:Alexa, where is mars in Portland (the app has just been opened).Alexa's answer:"I found a Venus and mars tanning in Portland... "  on and on about something other than what the app can do.Alexa, ask planetary ephemeris where mars is located in Portland.Mars is currently in the constellation of libra.For Portland, it is visible right now at 24 degree 02 minutes above the horizonthe asmith angle 211 degree 49 minutesIt will set today at local time, and rise tomorrow at 445 local timeit has a magnitude of 1.7Its right assention is 14 hours 36 minutes 12 secondsthe inclination ....  14 degree 36 seconds 37 secondsthe phase is 97.1% illuminatedThe angular diameter is 4.0 arc seconds.Conclusion:All I wanted to know was where Mars was located relative to S, SE, SW, or simply where to find it in the sky.This type of irrelevant answers related to my questions is typical.I'm giving both Alexa and this ephemeris app a 1 star.

title: Works great!!
date: Reviewed in the United States on December 31, 2017
content: This is a great skill, it even takes holidays into account. All you have to do is say ‚ÄúAlexa, ask Ottawa garbage when is the next pickup date‚Äù. Just like the instructions say... and the developer is really friendly and will update the skill if you add other wordings for using it.If you had a problem using it, it‚Äôs most likely because you didn‚Äôt invoke it properly, like you said ‚ÄúAlexa when is the next pickup date‚Äù and you left out the crucial ‚ÄúOttawa garbage‚Äù part. That‚Äôs a limitation amazon imposes on skills, not the developers fault. You can also say ‚ÄúAlexa open Ottawa garbage‚Äù if that‚Äôs easier for you.

title: Finally!
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 22, 2021
content: After playing around with it, I discovered the following small restrictions/quirks:1) It has a soft clock ticking sound while running. That's actually avery smart and very good thing (keep reading)....2) While it's running, you can still use your Echo to do things like turn lights on and off. You can also ask it questions (eg. "Who is the current president"). It will do those things and continue the soft ticking when done.  UPDATE:  HIT OR MISS.  These things can cause the skill to stop without notice.3) You cannot play music, streaming OR bluetooth, on THAT device while the skill is running. That stops the ticking, stops the skill. So the ticking at least reassures you the countdown has not been interrupted. You can stream music on other Alexa devices, though, so that's a great thing.4) Any "stop" command that you use while it is running will also stop the countdown.So, all in all, it's a very good skill among a ton of less-useful skills.  UPDATE:  Just run it on one of your Echos that you won‚Äôt interact with.  Also, it does not do minute by minute for long countdowns.  In a two-hour countdown, for example, the first announcement comes 15 minutes into the countdown, gradually increasing in frequency.  Please add a way to announce every minute.

title: I give 3 for concept but you can't dance to it
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 10, 2021
content: I absolutely loved the idea of having a destruct sequence. The launch phrase is good but I feel like there should be a couple of other statements that can get you there as well.I felt like they when on the cheap for the sound effects as they had a thin tinny kind of timbre. I would also like to jump on to the woodpile, stated in many of the other reviews, regarding the lack of "KABOOM!!" of some sort at the termination of the countdown. Perhaps I'm bringing my Boomer (ha! see what i did there?) non-nihilist aesthetic to this "it was said ironically" world; but, I found Alexa (I hope to god I didn't type that too loud or my bathroom lights are bound to start turning on and off) saying, "That's it." in as nonplussed a way as she can to be somewhat anticlimactic.For what is essentially $5, this routine should be better in sound quality for sure and, either executed on the straight and narrow or, had a better comic writer.

title: It works but...
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 13, 2018
content: I opened the stopwatch and then couldn't stop it! After 44 days, I found these reviews. After telling Alexa to "open" the stopwatch (and then she asks me if I want to open it, and I say yes), the way that I finally stopped it from running was: "Alexa, ask the stopwatch to delete."Who programmed this? I have things that I want to time fairly precisely, lasting from 10 seconds to 10 minutes. Going through three non-intuitive commands is NOT useful.

title: Go Back To the Drawing Board
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 25, 2017
content: All of the stopwatch skills have one FAULT which prevents them from being useful.  You can't PAUSE and RESUME.  Why is that so hard to understand?  Is it absolutely necessary to reset the stopwatch back to zero when it is stopped?  This skill is less useful than the other versions because in trying to make it more responsive to alternative commands Alexa is confused.  It is more accurate when there are precise commands.  "Alexa stop stopwatch.  Sorry I am having some trouble." "Alexa stopwatch stop. Tone."  "Alexa start stopwatch.  The Stopwatch has been running for 4 hours."

title: Brain dead app
date: Reviewed in the United States on October 27, 2018
content: This app is totally braindead. The commands are completely non-intuitive. Every time you ask for stopwatch it asks if you want to open it, even if it's running. It often gets confused with the daily status report and setting timers, which are completely different.Alexa, reset stopwatch -> "Alarm for what time?"Alexa, stopwatch reset -> "Here's your flash briefing from Reuters TV"Alexa, open stopwatch -> "Stopwatch is running at 42 mins...."Alexa, open stopwatch -> "You have stopwatch enabled, do you want to open it?" YES ->reset -> "To reset your device, unplug it from the back..."argh! worthless. I could go on , but times a wasting.....

title: Will not reset
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 7, 2020
content: Stopwatch currently running at 85+ days. Have tried numerous commands over weeks and nothing will stop it or reset it to zero. Request too many stopwatch commands and Alexa forgets she has a stopwatch function and will only respond with "Alarm set for what time?". Very frustrated.

title: Useless
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 24, 2020
content: I've tried every command recommended here, an every time I say "stopwatch," "she" says, Set alarm for what time? What is so difficult? I had a stopwatch in 1948 where you pushed a button to start, and one to stop. It cost me $1. Basically the Echo Dot with Clock is a clock. Fortunately, I needed that in the bedroom to note that I've awakened at 2 AM and now have six more hours to sleep.

title: Such a simple function made unnecessarily complicated
date: Reviewed in the United States on June 8, 2021
content: With all the other delightful things Alexa can do - intuitive things, where I don't have to look up instructions - I should be able to say, "Alexa, start a stopwatch," or "Alexa, time me," and she should do this, and stop when I say, "Alexa, stop my stopwatch."  Instead, I spent twice as long figuring out how to stop this function, as I did on the activity where I needed to time myself.  I learned from Johan, in the comments here, that you have to say, "Alexa, ask Stopwatch to _____." That does work, but it's a command that must have been created by a non-English speaker, because it is not intuitive.

title: Doesn't work
date: Reviewed in the United States on November 2, 2017
content: I read the prior review about issues and decided to try anyway due to the lack of other options. I ran into issues in asking for the status. I tried a couple different ways.Alexa ask stopwatch for status.Alexa ask stopwatch status.Both ways she responded with, "Stopwatch stopped and deleted."I then tried just to start and finish, no status requests.Alexa stop stopwatch.She responded, "Stopwatch stopped and deleted."Seems to be the only thing this skill can do is pretend to time things. Also, why assume I wanted to delete the time?

title: With a little trial and error I figured out how ...
date: Reviewed in the United States on May 2, 2018
content: With a little trial and error I figured out how to use the Stopwatch skill with my Echo Dot. I wonder if it's slightly different depending on the device. I  say "Alexa stopwatch" and it starts.  I say "Alexa stopwatch" a subsequent time and it tells me "Stopwatch running since x time. Restart, Delete, Continue?"

title: The state of AI in the early 21st century.
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 16, 2021
content: Good grief!  I don't even know if this is the stopwatch app in my Alexa. It appears there are many. But I asked her for a stopwatch and she loaded a recommendation.  Like lots of others, once it started I couldn't get it to stop.  I don't think AI is supposed to make you feel so stupid and frustrated you want to throw your Echo Dot into the microwave just to see what happens.  I had to laugh at myself and this idiot device that I'm sure costs $millions in development trying to do something I can do much easier with my $19 Casio watch from Walmart. I just thought it would be cool if Alexa could do it.  Apparently, AI is not as advanced as they show us in the movies. Fortunately, I found the reviews from other frustrated users telling me the 'magic' word. :-)BTW, the command was 'Alexa, delete stopwatch.'  (Who 'deletes' a stopwatch?)

title: Better than nothing?
date: Reviewed in the United States on April 4, 2021
content: Commands are awkward. Example: The stopwatch displays only when you say, "launch stopwatch" . That is the stopwatch starts ticking when you launch it. To see the stopwatch periodically you have to keep saying "launch stopwatch" . That means if the stopwatch is already running it just displays the current time elapsed. If you say "stop stopwatch" it displays the stopwatch, that is it does the same thing as "launch stopwatch" . You have to say "ask stopwatch to stop" or "ask stopwatch to delete" to actually stop the stopwatch. Way too awkward to use for precision timing!

title: It will never start
date: Reviewed in the United States on March 7, 2022

title: Annoying Specific Operational Syntax Required
date: Reviewed in the United States on August 17, 2021
content: I agree with the review and information provided by "Johann", dated June 17, 2018.  There is a very specific syntax required to make Stopwatch work.  It is not an inherently intuitive or short phrase which makes it very annoying to use and remember.You MUST use the following syntax:"Alexa, ask stopwatch to ________"The blank must be filled in with ONE word from the following choices:StartRestartContinueResetStatusDeleteI happen to have changed my "Alexa" to another name so, the correct syntax is:"<new name>, ask stopwatch to ________"So if you have changesd your Alexa call name, don't forget to use the correct new name.

title: DOes not understand well
date: Reviewed in the United States on January 16, 2017
content: I tried this, but it seldom understood what I was asking. It kept interpreting A as 8. It thought I said I when I said E. It seemed to time out often during questions. Generally, more frustration than it was worth. Easier to just pull up an ASCII table on the computer, especially since you would normally be on the computer when you need an ASCII value..
